title: From John O'Groats to Land's End; Or, 1372 miles on foot; A book of days and chronicle of adventures by two pedestrians on tour
author: Naylor, John Anderton
snippet: The Maiden Hill we could now see wassupposed to be one of the most stupendous British earthworks inexistence, quite as large as Old Sarum, and covering an area of 120acres.

title: From John O'Groats to Land's End; Or, 1372 miles on foot; A book of days and chronicle of adventures by two pedestrians on tour
author: Naylor, John Anderton
snippet: There was a fine view of the country from the top of the amphitheatre,and we could see both the Poundbury Camp and the Mai-Dun, or "Hill ofStrength," commonly called the Maiden Hill, a name also applied to otherhills we had seen in the country.
